repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

Related:
- #33444 
- https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/issues/3768
- https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3711#discussion_r2042332765

There are some type warning because `vim.lpeg.Pattern` is of type `userdata` and `vim.lpeg.type` cannot perform a sufficient narrowing.

I preferred not to mix up `string` and `Pattern` in something like `(string|vim.lpeg.Pattern)[]` to reduce code complexity.

CC @justinmk

comment_data.body:
rather than continue to add more overloads, this may need to be a kwargs arg
```suggestion
---@param names (string|string[]|table|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean) Names of the items to find.
```

and currently, the kwargs arg can support `{ glob: string }`. Then users can do `vim.fs.find({ glob = '*/*.txt' })`. WDYT @gpanders
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -248,7 +248,7 @@ end
 --- ```
 ---
 ---@since 10
----@param names (string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean) Names of the items to find.
+---@param names (string|string[]|vim.lpeg.Pattern|vim.lpeg.Pattern[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean) Names of the items to find.

comment_data.body:
Yeah that's much cleaner. The only reason I went with this approach is that I was already thinking about how it could integrate with `vim.fs.root()` and in `root_markers`

We could end up with something like:

```lua
root_markers = { { { glob = "*pattern" }, "lua_ls" }, ".git" }
```

So I thought a cleaner approach might be:

```
root_markers = { { vim.glob.to_lpeg("*pattern"), "lua_ls" }, ".git" }
```

That said, I haven't really looked into how many configurations would need this kind of `root_markers`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -248,7 +248,7 @@ end
 --- ```
 ---
 ---@since 10
----@param names (string|string[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean) Names of the items to find.
+---@param names (string|string[]|vim.lpeg.Pattern|vim.lpeg.Pattern[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean) Names of the items to find.

comment_data.body: I also thought about adding a flag to  `opts`, like `{ glob = true }`, but I don't know how it could be integrated with `root_markers`, unless everything is treated as a glob in `root_markers`.

comment_regular_data.body:
# Possible implementations

## Current (add function overload)

```lua
---@param names string|string[]|vim.lpeg.Pattern|vim.lpeg.Pattern[]|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean
---@param opts vim.fs.find.Opts
vim.fs.find(names, opts) end
```

This implementation adds two overloads, one for `vim.lpeg.Pattern` and one for `vim.lpeg.Pattern[]`.

**Pros**
- No modification to `vim.fs.root()` or `root_markers`.

**Cons**
- Hard to typecheck `userdata` type.
- Ugly function signature.

## @justinmk's version (add kwargs)

```lua
---@param names: string|string[]|table|fun(name: string, path: string): boolean
vim.fs.find(names, opts) end
```

Where `table` is just a kwarg which containts `{ glob = "*mypattern*" }`.

**Pros**
- Easy to typecheck
- Very readable.

**Cons**
- Need to update `vim.fs.root()` and `root_markers` to handle it.
- To handle multiple globs with the same priority in `root_markers` we would need to add `table[]` to `---@param names`.
- `root_markers` can become quite hard to read: `{ { { glob = "*lua.toml" }, "luarc.json" }, ".git"}`

## Opt-in glob version

Add `glob: boolean` to `vim.fs.find.Opts`, so it can be used as

```lua
vim.fs.find({ "*mypattern*", ".git" }, { glob = true })
```

**Pros**
- Easy to use
- Easy to implement

**Cons**
- `vim.fs.root()` needs to accept some kind of `opt`.
- Pattern matching is done for all element if there's just one pattern.
- In `root_markers` invocations of `vim.fs.root()` would all have `{ glob = true }`, which is not performant.

## Conclusion

None of them satisfies me completely, so let me know what you think!

The minimum first step here is to add the `{ glob = "*mypattern*" }`. We can consider function overloads or whatever later. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33444#issuecomment-3303659429

We also need this for the `filetypes` field of `vim.lsp.config`.

> Test failure

How come tests fail only with zig builds? Is it something common?

> Yes, look at [1f00497#diff-22260c58f0aad18ee7f70b3ae84f09fe6537b4136a2e0b87952ca560f81f1e7a](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/1f004970f00bd8ef7ad955b52857df136f82185b#diff-22260c58f0aad18ee7f70b3ae84f09fe6537b4136a2e0b87952ca560f81f1e7a)

I cannot seem to correctly build with zig (I have not experience with zig), and I can't find any build instructions. If I run `zig build` it hangs at "Fetch packages: lua_dev_deps"

> > Yes, look at [1f00497#diff-22260c58f0aad18ee7f70b3ae84f09fe6537b4136a2e0b87952ca560f81f1e7a](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/1f004970f00bd8ef7ad955b52857df136f82185b#diff-22260c58f0aad18ee7f70b3ae84f09fe6537b4136a2e0b87952ca560f81f1e7a)
> 
> I cannot seem to correctly build with zig (I have not experience with zig), and I can't find any build instructions. If I run `zig build` it hangs at "Fetch packages: lua_dev_deps"

Managed to manually fetch `lua_dev_deps`, by looking at: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a0c60e819df1b4d4ae5ac631d48e874fa1cf9b92/.github/workflows/test.yml#L234-L249

But building on macos still hangs while fetching `libiconv`. Maybe I should file an issue.

EDIT:

I managed to run the test under linux with zig. The test with find and globs doesn't fail anymore, but others still do. We'll see if the runner fails or not.
